raw_text:
Spark heads world Booker list
 
 Dame Muriel Spark is among three British authors who have made the shortlist for the inaugural international Booker Prize.
 
 Doris Lessing and Ian McEwan have also been nominated. McEwan and Margaret Atwood are the only nominees to have previously won the main Booker Prize. The new £60,000 award is open to writers of all nationalities who write in English or are widely translated. The prize commends an author for their body of work instead of one book.
 
 Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Saul Bellow, Milan Kundera and John Updike also feature on the 18-strong list of world literary figures.
 
 But other past winners of the regular Booker Prize, such as Salman Rushdie, JM Coetzee and Kazuo Ishiguro have failed to make the shortlist. The prize, which will be awarded in London in June, will be given once every two years. It will reward an author - who must be living - for "continued creativity, development and overall contribution to fiction on the world stage". An author can only win once. The international award was started in response to criticisms that the Booker Prize is only open to British and Commonwealth authors.
 
 
 
 Margaret Atwood (Canada) Saul Bellow (Canada) Gabriel Garcia Marquez (Colombia) Gunter Grass (Germany) Ismail Kadare (Albania) Milan Kundera (Czech Republic) Stanislaw Lem (Poland) Doris Lessing (UK) Ian McEwan (UK) Naguib Mahfouz (Egypt) Tomas Eloy Martinez (Argentina) Kenzaburo Oe (Japan) Cynthia Ozick (US) Philip Roth (US) Muriel Spark (UK) Antonio Tabucchi (Italy) John Updike (US) Abraham B Yehoshua (Israel)
llama3.2:1b: Dame Muriel Spark, Doris Lessing, Ian McEwan, and Margaret Atwood are among three British authors shortlisted for the inaugural international Booker Prize.
llama3.2:3b: Dame Muriel Spark is among three British authors nominated for the inaugural international Booker Prize, which also includes Doris Lessing and Ian McEwan.
Other notable nominees include Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Saul Bellow, Milan Kundera, and John Updike.
The prize aims to recognize an author's "continued creativity, development and overall contribution to fiction on the world stage" every two years, starting in June in London, with a £60,000 award.

qwen2.5:3b: Dame Muriel Spark is among three British authors nominated for the inaugural international Booker Prize, which opens to writers from all nationalities writing in English or widely translated.
Also included are Doris Lessing and Ian McEwan, who have previously won the main Booker Prize.
The prize awards an author's body of work instead of a single book, with winners being restricted to one award.
Past winners like Salman Rushdie and Kazuo Ishiguro did not make this shortlist due to criticisms that the regular Booker Prize is limited to British and Commonwealth authors.
Notable figures on the list include Gabriel García Márquez, Saul Bellow, Milan Kunderra, John Updike, among others from various countries.
opencoder:1.5b: The text presents a summary of the given text.

The key ideas and details about the authors who have won the Booker Prize are summarized as follows:

- Author Margaret Atwood (Canada) has been chosen to win the Booker Prize.
- Author Saul Bellow (Canada) also made the list.
- Author Gabriel Garcia Marquez (Colombia) and Gunter Grass (Germany) also participated in the Booker Prize.
- Author Stanislaw Lem (Poland) has also won the list.

- The remaining authors, including Doris Lessing (UK), Ian McEwan (UK), Tomas Eloy Martinez (Argentina), Kenzaburo Oe (Japan), Cynthia Ozick (US), Philip Roth (US), and Antonio Tabucchi (Italy) have also participated in the list.
They have not won the Booker Prize yet.

- The authors who write in English or are widely translated have also contributed to the list, but they will not be considered as they haven't made the initial list selection due to their nationality.

Yehoshu'a.
